body: Resolved via: 0512a23454375156a0fb152e68c0ecdd63689ac6
ac5244748f7cf0dec1b205b215f2284db2a342fc resolves
@kuanb let me know if this makes sense to you.

From Kele: 

If possible, I’d like to know:
·        How many clients have responded back

·        Can we tell if the number isn’t valid? (they gave us a fake number)

·        A break out of staff name and # of messages (to see the high utilizers of the system?).  We can use the data to see if clients are completing successfully or initiating based on reminders.
Resolved via c736d187be87edacdaba16b7a04e622d174bbbe6
Issue was not resolved, that was only to the /sms POST endpoint, but fails to accommodate for user input on cm response
back to all clients
also a single convo needs to be that (group msg so all cms can see persons being contacted, not redundant ones)

Rather than truncate a message over 160 characters, what about generating a pop up message and disabling the send button after 160 is reached?

@kuanb This also raises the question if we should limit emails to the same length so that the message rules don't change when the delivery method changes.

You are receiving this email because your Twilio account has encountered an error or warning and the On 1st error every day Alert Trigger has fired. The most recent alert was:
11200 - HTTP retrieval failure
View the Monitor Alerts Log for your account.

Alert Trigger   *
Trigger Value   1
Current Value   1
Recurring   Daily
Ben that will be a front end feature. This has to do with mechanics of the internal POST API. We can add responsive UX features, too. I've already limited the text box to 160 chars.

resolved via ^
Clients should never be removed perhaps but only turned "off"
Do we need to account for OTN overlap? I dont think so for now... maybe we just roll with the clients being separate and not having to be unique
Okay for now I think. We have heard that people use aliases. If we can account for OTN overlap in the future and flag when that happens its a bonus.

re-opening one convo will close another, i think for the case of accidentally closing  a convo this makes sense
This is a "down the road" solution for when phone calls are enabled.

Need to discuss if we do want to implement this. The request suggests that there would be the ability for a supervisor to see a CMs texts... is this ok? I don't think so - due to CM - Client confidentiality... Perhaps just a warning to the Super if the CM has not viewed a text message in over 2 days?
In general, this view needs to be cleaned up. Agreed.

Difference between this and last one? https://github.com/slco-2016/clientcomm/issues/5

Could both be combined?
